title: It's late, so take this with a grain of salt.
body:
WHAT IF...

We were to take a champion that is somewhat of a pain to balance in a solo lane due to becoming a brick wall and reworked him to fit into a DUO lane.
No, I'm not talking about {{champion:82}}, I'm talking about 
http://img08.deviantart.net/7244/i/2014/185/b/0/aatrox_by_alimika-d7p9jjo.png

Now, before you get your pitchforks and call me a hypocrite let me explain.

Aatrox suffers from a very specific problem; He lacks anything that makes him unique and delivers on his THEME of a demon of WAR, who invigorates the losing side to overcome all odds and emerge victorious.
It does make him sound more like a support-y kind of character who'll fight alongside weaker "allies" to lead them to victory. Somewhat of a battlemaster support.

Just like Mordekaiser he could benefit from a rework that delivered on his themes and made him unique and NOT the generic Diver kit with a demon-warrior wrapping.
He needs to be more satisfying to play and provide cool and unique ways to deliver on his theme and bring something to the table.

Now, I know, this might just be a stupid idea but in THEORY; Would making Aatrox a support-y fighter work, one that could potentially be played as a SUPPORT in a DUO lane or just roll top or Jungle if he had to?

A Battlemaster would differ from your usual Healing and Peel support in that he lacks raw UTILITY but offers specific in COMBAT bonuses that allows him to dictate the flow of battle, providing specific bonuses to his allies in form of buffs that help them do their job.

They'd lack healing like Soraka, pure peel like Janna, heavy CC like Alistar and Nautilus but offer more OFFENSIVE buffs.
They'd be able to accent their allies strengths by allowing them to succeed in combat rather than offering simple things like peel and co.

Susceptible to being picked off one by one or having assassins just dive their carries but deadly in an all out WAR (5v5)

Let me explain why:

So what he sounds like to me (in his new form and role) is as an Aura Provider champion, which is the reason why Sona was garbage for years. Auras provide quite powerful stats for the entire team but the bad thing about them is that the power is invisible as it is passive in nature. Just stat boosts that don't leave any visible traces, making them feel incredibly lackluster because the champion that provides them does literally nothing but stand near his team and provides "moral" support. Auras need to be incredibly powerful for a single person in order to be visibly powerful and that would simply mean the champion would be a pick/ban material for who knows how long.
_**Just look at Lucio in Overwatch.**_

Furthermore, you'd want for a solo top laner/jungler to be reworked into a duo lane support?

Although i am not opposed to the idea of an "offensive action" support, i don't believe Aatrox is the champion for that role. As an Aatrox main who loves the champion for both his thematic and his gameplay, I'm pretty opposed to this. 

Making him into a support delivers slightly more on his thematic of leading battle, but at his core Aatrox is still a bloodthirsty god of war, and whether he has allies to share in the bloodshed or not really adds little to him. Aatrox would be just as happy fighting everyone and leaving all but one dead just so they could tell his tale.

Going the support route also destroys the things about Aatrox's kit that I really love. The clutch moments when you're at 5% HP and every time you heal you get a spike of health just large enough to survive. The strong burst of his empowered W. His E and R that are great damage tools that everyone forgets about. His passive making him almost impossible to kill if you actually play well and keep track of when to fight. 

Aatrox definitely has problems. He's a little on the weak side (I'm not gonna sit here and day he's garbage, because he's not, he just takes a much higher level of skill and experience to play effectively than someone like Jax or Irelia) but he can still do useful things. His kit has some unhealthy mechanics and some other mechanics that are simply poor design choices and don't deliver as well as they should. But I don't think that pushing him into the support role is the right way to fix these problems.
Hear, hear. These non-Aatrox players that think they know what we want! Pfft.
You really understand what I and most Aatrox players love. I think he inspires people just by being a boss. His dance speaks for itself, no non boss could pull off moves like that

On the subject, I think it would be cool to see a champion that's a master tactician/strategist. And when I say that, I mean an actual tactician, not a dude who turns into a bird and kills people with magic :P

With the way they described him, he should have been a support. And it's not like he wouldn't fit. We have a sadistic ghost jailer as a top support.

Edit: Also I think "Warlord" sounds better than "Battlemaster".

I personally don't want my main champion, who was always designated as a damage dealer to be moved into the support role. He is a diver and is being reworked as a diver. The "fight to the death" and "inspiring" his allies was only a method to stir more bloodshed and cause more havoc on the battlefield. Aatrox is a selfish character, he is not in it to 'help' anyone, he thrives off meaningless wars and does not care who wins or loses. He is a do as he pleases type of guy, if he wants to prolong a war - sure he'll give a 'helping hand'. The consequence being his help can cause numerous types of side effects related to blood-thirst and violence.

Whilst I appreciate the idea, I really don't agree with this direction for this rework. You're basically doing what they did to Morderkaiser. You're taking a champion that some people really enjoy and forcing it into alien territory on some whim that it may work. Whether or not it will work is not the problem, the problem is Aatrox already has some kind of established identity to those who've played him. He has ONLY been ever played seriously in the top, mid or jungle. Why force a champion to undergo such a transformation, forcing a MAJOR rework when you can indeed fix him up to be much more healthy in the role he was intended to be? I feel this battlemaster/tactician you desire should be built from the ground up as a different champion rather than built around a vague possibility of an established champion.

tl;dr - you leave aatrox alone. let him be the generic demon war guy that we aatrox players all know and love. use that idea to make a new champion instead, it seems to be a decent idea.

I can't speak to the rest of what you said, but this stuck out. Right now the game has plenty of diver type fighters, whereas what MM is describing would be the first of its kind.

Just because there is potential for something to be good doesn't mean that you should do it.
The issue with this entire concept is that it banks on the idea that the players WHO ACTUALLY PLAY THE CHAMPION will be down for having their champion's identity COMPLETELY REPLACED all because some random folk on the boards thought it would be fun to dream up a concept that is much better suited for a new champion.
Putting this in Riot's perspective, why would they go out of their way and put EVEN more work on themselves for a major rework overhauling a champions ENTIRE kit when they could have easily just fixed him up in a smaller scope/moderate rework and save this other concept for a later champion design?

If you still don't get it, then listen... It's not about the 'potential' that frightens me, it's you folk and your lack of ethics when regarding an entire community and player-base that does. I'm sure avid Morderkaiser players were not happy when they GIMPED Morderkaiser and forced him into the role of 'ADC' and I'm sure you wouldn't be happy if your main champion was changed into something else all because of the possibility that it "would be the first of its kind". So, why then is it that you think it's fair game to put Aatrox and his community on the chopping block for your dubious experiments?

If all Aatrox needed was some small changes then I feel Riot would have done that years ago. 

I understand your frustration (I've seen it a bunch of times with every rework) but I feel a lot of these only focus on what the champion means to them and not what the champion means to the game as a whole. 

The problem with Aatrox (IMO) is that his lore presence and gameplay are too different. Each has a different aspect that's supposed to make him stand out. 

Lore Aatrox is some warrior who makes a habit of turning the tides and invoking bloodlust in warriors that would have lost otherwise. He basically inspires people. 

Gameplay Aatrox is a sustain champion with a revive mechanic that either beats you with better numbers, or is useless. He's not very inspiring. 

Now you are correct that such a concept would work for a new champion. But why build up a new character with this concept when we already have one with the right background. We don't need a champion that's "what Aatrox should have been". 

Plus war isn't just combat. It's more strategy than anything else. It would make sense for a "God of war" to be somewhat tactical.

I could see them doing this in the future, but honestly, I think we need to figure out where support is going as a class first. If these queue times end up messing with things enough, Riot is going to take a hard look at support. 

They are spending an awful lot of time and effort on mitigating the problems to ignore the core issue. If things don't improve, I wouldn't be surprised to find out they were going to make supports the next big class update. Or possibly next pre-season.

> If things don't improve, I wouldn't be surprised to find out they were going to make supports the next big class update. Or possibly next pre-season. 

While a support role class update could potentially lead to some really big "wins" for Riot, I don't see something that small in scope really fixing the problem.
Support role problems are systemic to the design of the game. 4 gold/xp revenues, 5 champions, asymmetrical map, a design philosophy that utility is toxic in large amounts (Riot's getting better about this one), and the emphasis on snowballing for shorter games.
This combination of factors are what makes the support role such an undesirable position. The game *by design* doesn't encourage supports, but requires someone that can handle the short straw.

Unfortunately, this is a common element among MOBA clones right now. It's not unique to LoL. Which is why a "class update" wouldn't be enough.
It's also a large reason why I was looking forward to Dawngate (RiP) taking off. The address a lot of these problems.
How'd they address supports?

They didn't really address supports specifically, their game was better designed to eliminate or mitigate the problems support role has in traditional MOBA format.

1. Excluding Mina, Dawngate "supports" weren't designed to be slaves. The Dev's went so far as to state they wanted to move away from that mind-set.

2. Symmetry
Dawngate had 2 lanes and 1 jungle. The primary jungle objective was in the center of the map. Each quarter of the map was symmetrical to it's opposite.
This means each lane carries the same amount of power and importance. Excluding jungler and "role", it didn't matter who went where. 

3. Revenue
Dawngate had 4 "roles" that you selected from before each match. These dictated where the majority of your gold came from.
These were passive benefits selected at the start of the game - not items. They had a drastic affect on your income, ensuring there was minimal competition for CS,kills,etc. (Most common comp was 2 glad, 2 tact, 1 hunt
 - Gladiator: CS
 - Tactician: Lane minion deaths (talisman), and harass (FQC)
 - Hunter: smite + hunter's machete/talisman
 - Predator: Kills/assists and damaging Spirit wells (Affected team passive income). Bonus exp on kills/assists.

In this context, supports weren't defined as being "the champions who can survive on almost nothing". They were there because they were genuinely needed for the team. They weren't trapped into only going one place because every location (jung, 2 lanes) had the same amount of power (where as Riot insists on making bot lane the most important).

oh, almost forgot.
4. Wards
 - Everybody got a 1 ward trinket. That was it. No sight stone. No sweepers. No pinks.
If you wanted more vision, you played Ronan. His wards ignored brush and terrain.
Dawngate.......sweet memories.... how i miss that game..
